com.stormpath.sdk.client

Interface ApiKeyBuilder

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    ApiKeyBuilder
    Deprecated. 
    in 1.0.RC and will be removed before 1.0 final. Use ApiKeyBuilder instead.

    @Deprecated
public interface ApiKeyBuilder
    A Builder design pattern used to construct ApiKey instances.

    The ApiKeyBuilder is especially useful for constructing ApiKey instances with Stormpath API Key information loaded from an external .properties file (or Properties instance) to ensure the API Key secret (password) does not reside in plaintext in code.

    Assuming you stored your API Key in your home directory per Stormpath's instructions, you would create your api key object as follows: 

     String location = System.getProperty("user.home") + "/.stormpath/apiKey.properties";

 ApiKey apiKey = ApiKeys.builder().setFileLocation(location).build();
    Then, you will create your Client instance as follows: 
     Client client = Clients.builder().setApiKey(apiKey).build();

    You may load files from the filesystem, classpath, or URLs by prefixing the path with file:, classpath:, or url: respectively. See setFileLocation(String) for more information.

    Since:
    1.0.beta
    See Also:
    setFileLocation(String), ClientBuilder.setApiKey(ApiKey)

    • Method Detail

      • setId

        @Deprecated
ApiKeyBuilder setId(String id)
        Deprecated. in 1.0.RC and will be removed before 1.0 final. Use ApiKeyBuilder.setId(String) instead.
        Allows specifying the client's API Key id value directly instead of reading it from a stream-based resource (e.g. File, Reader, Properties or InputStream).

        Usage Warning

        It is almost always advisable to NOT use this method and instead use methods that accept a stream-based resource (File, Reader, Properties or InputStream): these other methods would ideally acquire the API Key from a secure and private apiKey.properties file that is readable only by the process that uses the Stormpath SDK.

        This builder method is provided however for environments that do not have access to stream resources or files, such as in certain application hosting providers or Platform-as-a-Service environments like Heroku.

        Environment Variables

        In these restricted environments, the ApiKey id and secret would almost always be obtained from environment variables, for example: 
         String id = System.getenv("STORMPATH_API_KEY_ID");
 String secret = System.getenv("STORMPATH_API_KEY_SECRET");
 ApiKey apiKey = ApiKeys.builder().setId(id).setSecret(secret).build();
 Client client = Clients.builder().setApiKey(apiKey).build();

        System Properties

        It is not recommended to load the ApiKey id and secret from a system property, for example:

        THIS IS NOT RECOMMENDED. THIS COULD BE A SECURITY RISK: 

         String apiKeySecret = System.getProperty("STORMPATH_API_KEY_SECRET");
        This is not recommended because System properties are visible in process listings, e.g. on Unix/Linux/MacOS: 
        
 $ ps aux
        You do not want your API Key Secret visible by anyone who can do a process listing!

        Hard Coding

        It is NEVER recommended to embed the raw ApiKey values in source code that would be committed to version control (like Git or Subversion):

        THIS IS AN ANTI-PATTERN! DO NOT DO THIS! THIS IS A SECURITY RISK! 

         String id = "myRawApiKeyId";
 String secret = "secretValueThatAnyoneCouldSeeIfTheyCheckedOutMySourceCode";
 ApiKey apiKey = ApiKeys.builder().setId(id).setSecret(secret).build();
 Client client = Clients.builder().setApiKey(apiKey).build();
        Parameters:
        id - the ApiKey id to use when communicating with Stormpath.
        Returns:
        the ApiKeyBuilder instance for method chaining.
        See Also:
        ClientBuilder.setApiKey(ApiKey)

      • setSecret

        @Deprecated
ApiKeyBuilder setSecret(String secret)
        Deprecated. in 1.0.RC and will be removed before 1.0 final. Use ApiKeyBuilder.setSecret(String) instead.
        Allows specifying the client's API Key secret value directly instead of reading it from a stream-based resource (e.g. File, Reader, Properties or InputStream).

        For usage instructions and security precautions see setId(String)

        Parameters:
        secret - the ApiKey id to use when communicating with Stormpath.
        Returns:
        the ApiKeyBuilder instance for method chaining.
        See Also:
        setId(String), ClientBuilder.setApiKey(ApiKey)

      • setProperties

        @Deprecated
ApiKeyBuilder setProperties(Properties properties)
        Deprecated. in 1.0.RC and will be removed before 1.0 final. Use ApiKeyBuilder.setProperties(Properties) instead.
        Allows usage of a Properties instance instead of loading a .properties file via fileLocation configuration.

        The Properties contents and property name overrides function the same as described in the setFileLocation JavaDoc.

        Parameters:
        properties - the properties instance to use to load the API Key ID and Secret.
        Returns:
        the ApiKeyBuilder instance for method chaining.

      • setReader

        @Deprecated
ApiKeyBuilder setReader(Reader reader)
        Deprecated. in 1.0.RC and will be removed before 1.0 final. Use ApiKeyBuilder.setReader(Reader) instead.
        Creates an API Key Properties instance based on the specified Reader instead of loading a .properties file via fileLocation configuration.

        The constructed Properties contents and property name overrides function the same as described in the setFileLocation JavaDoc.

        Parameters:
        reader - the reader to use to construct a Properties instance.
        Returns:
        the ApiKeyBuilder instance for method chaining.

      • setInputStream

        @Deprecated
ApiKeyBuilder setInputStream(InputStream is)
        Deprecated. in 1.0.RC and will be removed before 1.0 final. Use ApiKeyBuilder.setInputStream(InputStream) instead.
        Creates an API Key Properties instance based on the specified InputStream instead of loading a .properties file via fileLocation configuration.

        The constructed Properties contents and property name overrides function the same as described in the setFileLocation JavaDoc.

        Parameters:
        is - the InputStream to use to construct a Properties instance.
        Returns:
        the ApiKeyBuilder instance for method chaining.

      • setFileLocation

        @Deprecated
ApiKeyBuilder setFileLocation(String location)
        Deprecated. in 1.0.RC and will be removed before 1.0 final. Use ApiKeyBuilder.setFileLocation(String) instead.
        Sets the location of the .properties file to load containing the API Key (Id and secret) used by the Client to communicate with the Stormpath REST API.

        You may load files from the filesystem, classpath, or URLs by prefixing the location path with file:, classpath:, or url: respectively. If no prefix is found, file: is assumed by default.

        File Contents

        When the file is loaded, the following name/value pairs are expected to be present by default:

        Key Value
        apiKey.id An individual account's API Key ID
        apiKey.secret The API Key Secret (password) that verifies the paired API Key ID.

        Assuming you were using these default property names, your ClientBuilder usage might look like the following: 

         String location = "/home/jsmith/.stormpath/apiKey.properties";

 ApiKey apiKey = ApiKeys.builder().setFileLocation(location).build();
 Client client = Clients.builder().setApiKey(apiKey).build();

        Custom Property Names

        If you want to control the property names used in the file, you may configure them via setIdPropertyName and setSecretPropertyName.

        For example, if you had a /home/jsmith/.stormpath/apiKey.properties file with the following name/value pairs: 

         myStormpathApiKeyId = foo
 myStormpathApiKeySecret = mySuperSecretValue
        Your ClientBuilder usage would look like the following: 
         String location = "/home/jsmith/.stormpath/apiKey.properties";

 Client client =
     Clients.builder()
     .setApiKey(
          ApiKeys.builder()
          .setFileLocation(location)
          .setIdPropertyName("myStormpathApiKeyId")
          .setSecretPropertyName("myStormpathApiKeySecret")
          .build())
     .build();
        Parameters:
        location - the file, classpath or url location of the API Key .properties file to load when constructing the API Key to use for communicating with the Stormpath REST API.
        Returns:
        the ApiKeyBuilder instance for method chaining.

      • setIdPropertyName

        @Deprecated
ApiKeyBuilder setIdPropertyName(String idPropertyName)
        Deprecated. in 1.0.RC and will be removed before 1.0 final. Use ApiKeyBuilder.setIdPropertyName(String) instead.
        Sets the name used to query for the API Key ID from a Properties instance. That is: 
         String apiKeyId = properties.getProperty(idPropertyName);
        Parameters:
        idPropertyName - the name used to query for the API Key ID from a Properties instance.
        Returns:
        the ApiKeyBuilder instance for method chaining.

      • setSecretPropertyName

        @Deprecated
ApiKeyBuilder setSecretPropertyName(String secretPropertyName)
        Deprecated. in 1.0.RC and will be removed before 1.0 final. Use ApiKeyBuilder.setSecretPropertyName(String) instead.
        Sets the name used to query for the API Key Secret from a Properties instance. That is: 
         String apiKeySecret = properties.getProperty(secretPropertyName);
        Parameters:
        secretPropertyName - the name used to query for the API Key Secret from a Properties instance.
        Returns:
        the ApiKeyBuilder instance for method chaining.

      • build

        @Deprecated
ApiKey build()
        Deprecated. in 1.0.RC and will be removed before 1.0 final. Use ApiKeyBuilder.build() instead.
        Constructs a new ApiKey instance based on the ApiKeyBuilder's current configuration state.
        Returns:
        a new ApiKey instance based on the ApiKeyBuilder's current configuration state.
